Confined pyrolysis transformation of ZIF-8 to hierarchically ordered porous Zn-N-C nanoreactor for efficient CO2 photoconversion under mild conditions Yingchun Guo Lei Feng Changcheng Wu Xiaomei Wang ⁎ Xu Zhang ⁎ Hebei Key Laboratory of Functional Polymers, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China Hebei Key Laboratory of Functional Polymers School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China Hebei Key Laboratory of Functional Polymers, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Rational design and fabrication of metal–organic framework (MOF)-derived ordered hierarchical macro-/meso-/microporous N-doped carbon materials featured with the atomically dispersed metal atoms can effectively enhance their catalytic performance. Herein we develop a template-assisted strategy, namely the confined growth and pyrolysis of single-crystalline zeolite imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) in three-dimensional ordered template voids, to create hierarchical porosity in MOFs-derived N-doped carbon materials. The as-synthesized single-atom Zn on N-doped hierarchically ordered porous carbon polyhedrons (Zn-N-HOPCPs) show integrated Lewis acid (single-atom Zn) and base sites (pyridinic N), high surface area (1128 m2·g−1), large pore volume (0.90 cm3·g−1), periodically interconnected open windows (~55 nm), highly accessible micro/mesopore channels (0.55, 0.8, 1.2, and 4 nm), and abundant Zn content (5.8 wt%). The hierarchical nanoarchitecture (macro-/meso-/micropores) significantly facilitates mass transfer for bulky-molecule-involved reactions and exposes inside active sites, resulting in satisfactory CO2 photoconversion under mild conditions. The strategy presented here sheds light on the design and fabrication of various hierarchically ordered porous carbon decorated with atomically dispersed metal atoms for other important applications. Keywords Hierarchically ordered porous MOF Confined pyrolysis N-doped porous carbon Single Zn atoms CO2 cycloaddition 1 Introduction The large depletion of carbon-rich fossil fuels has significantly increased the content of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere, triggering a series of serious environmental problems such as greenhouse effect and ocean acidification [1–3]. Meanwhile, CO2 is also recognized as an environmentally abundant, inexpensive, non-toxic, and renewable C1 carbon source, which can be converted into high value-added chemicals through chemical transformation [4,5]. Among various CO2 capture and conversion, the cycloaddition of epoxides with CO2 has also aroused intense interest, because the resultant products cyclic carbonates have been extensively used as monomers for engineering plastics, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, intermediates for the pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals, and polar aprotic solvents [6–9]. Recently, a wide range of catalysts including both homogeneous and heterogeneous types have been designed for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides, including ionic liquids, Schiff bases, metal complexes, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), and porous hyper-crosslinked polymers [10–13]. Among these catalytic systems, homogeneous catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity but suffer from not easily separated and reused. On the contrary, heterogeneous catalysts are easy to separate and reuse but are constrained by the low reactivity and inferior mass diffusion. Therefore, the delicate design and fabrication of high-performance heterogeneous catalysts are greatly desired. In view of the green and sustainable approach, the development of visible-light-driven photocatalysts for the conversion of CO2 to value-added energy products or chemicals could be a judicious choice [14,15]. Especially, it is greatly significant that the high-efficiently photocatalytic conversion of CO2 occurs at normal temperature and pressure. By mimicking natural photosynthesis, the heating is replaced by renewable solar energy such that the endothermic reaction is driven by the photothermal effect of the photocatalyst [16]. Currently, N-doped porous carbon nanomaterial decorated with single-atom catalysts (SACs) have been widely considered as a promising photocatalyst for CO2 conversion because of its supreme atom-utilization efficiency and distinct properties [17–19]. Upon high-temperature carbonization, MOFs can be converted to transition metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C, M: Zn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, etc.) materials which can effectively harvest sunlight and then release them into the surrounding environment by thermal radiation [20–24]. For example, Zeolite imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) has been used as a support precursor to fabricate Zn-N-C which has been proven to be ideal photocatalyst for CO2 conversion due to the synergistic catalysis of pyridinic N and single Zn atoms [25]. As is well-known, specific surface area and porous structure are responsible for mass transport and the light-harvesting efficiency [26–30]. To date, tremendous efforts have been devoted to the focus on bulky ZIF-derived carbon materials [31–35]. Unfortunately, most reported ZIF-derived carbon materials exhibit porosities restricted to the micropore-dominated porous structure, which severely occludes the accessibility of the internal surface and limits the diffusion of the molecules within the material [36–39]. The micropore-dominated catalysts make it exhibit a relatively low activity in catalyzing bulky-molecule-involved reactions. Converting the bulky ZIF-derived carbon materials into a macroporous structure so that the reactant molecules can contact and react with the internal active site is an effective approach to improve its catalytic performance. Generally, the hard template method is employed as the most common way of generating high quality ordered macroporous materials [40–43]. Ordered macro-microporous MOFs single crystals and MOFs-derived carbon materials can be prepared by controlling the crystal growth of crystalline porous materials in a 3D-ordered colloidal crystal template (CCT, all abbreviations are shown in Table S1) [44–46]. The conversion of MOFs into 3D-ordered macroporous (3DOM) carbon materials via pyrolysis using organic CCT (linear polystyrene (LPS) or polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA)) usually involves four steps: synthesis of the CCT, growth of the MOF in the CCT voids, template removal, and pyrolysis of the 3DOM-MOF [47]. It is well known that MOFs undergo the overall structural shrinkage during the high-temperature carbonization process due to the conversion of organic ligands into carbon [48,49]. Compared with organic CCT, the high-temperature resistance of SiO2-CCT allows SiO2-CCT@MOF composites to be carbonized before removing the template in the preparation of 3DOM-MOFs-derived carbon materials. The SiO2-CCT acts as a physical barrier to prevent morphology collapse and excessive shrinkage while preventing the agglomeration of metal nanoparticles during calcination [50]. Consequently, the fabrication of M-N-C materials with both large specific surface area and desirable porous structure through a hard-template-assisted process is extremely attractive to expose interior active sites as well as to expedite the molecules transfer and enhance light-harvesting efficiency. Inspired by the above concerns, herein, we elaborately designed a template-assisted pyrolysis strategy to fabricate single-atom Zn on N-doped hierarchically ordered porous carbon polyhedrons (Zn-N-HOPCPs) by the pyrolysis of composites comprising ZIF-8 single crystals filled with SiO2-CCT. During carbonization, SiO2-CCT is employed as hard templates, which mainly contribute to the formation of 3D ordered interconnected macropores within the N-doped carbon polyhedrons. The obtained Zn-N-HOPCPs are ideal photocatalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides at ambient temperature and low pressure, because of the following merits. Firstly, the 3D ordered interconnected macropores can improve light-harvesting ability via multiple reflections of light and facilitate diffusion and transport of substrates/products molecules, especially enable Zn-N-HOPCPs to catalyze more bulky-molecule-involved reaction. Secondly, hierarchical porosity with the high surface area can enrich CO2 and epoxides molecules and provide abundant active site exposure. Thirdly, the atomically dispersed Zn/N active sites maximize the catalytic efficiency of the atom. Fourthly, the robust 3D framework structures enable Zn-N-HOPCPs to be easily separated and recycled. For comparison, single-atom Zn on N-doped bulky micro/mesoporous carbon polyhedrons (Zn-N-BMCPs) were fabricated via direct carbonization of bulky ZIF-8 polyhedrons without SiO2-CCT. The single-atom Zn on N-doped hierarchically ordered porous carbon monolith (Zn-N-HOPCM) were also prepared by repeatedly encapsulating ZIF-8 into the void of SiO2-CCT, followed by pyrolysis. Investigation of their catalytic efficiency in the conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates under the same experimental conditions revealed significant differences between the three catalytic systems which greatly depend on the morphology of the composite. With the structural advantage, the Zn-N-HOPCPs exhibited much better activity in the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 98%), 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIM, 99%), tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, 99.5%), and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, Mw ~ 40000) were purchased from Shanghai DiBai Bio-technology Co., Ltd. Methanol (CH3OH, 99%) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 96%) were obtained from Tianjin Hengshan Chemical Corporation. Popylene oxide (99%), 3-bromopropylene oxide (99%), 2-butyloxirane (99%), 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane (99%), and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB, 98%) were received from Aladdin. Carbon dioxide gas was obtained from Tianjin Dongrun Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Fabrication of SiO2-CCT SiO2 nanospheres were prepared according to the classical stöber method with slight modification. First, ammonia hydroxide (8.5 g) is poured into a mixture of ethanol (167 mL) and deionized water (16 mL), and the mixed solution was stirred at 25 °C for 30 min. Then TEOS (15 mL) is poured into the above-obtained solution and the reaction solution was kept stirring under 25 °C for 8 h to obtain SiO2 nanospheres. The gained SiO2 nanospheres were dispersed 100 mL aqueous solution containing PVP (1.0 g) and vigorously stirred at 80 °C for 12 h. The modified SiO2 nanospheres were collected by centrifugation and formed into a monolithic SiO2 colloidal crystal template. Finally, the dried SiO2-CCT was sintered at 100 °C for 1 day to yield a robust opalescent piece. 2.3 Synthesis of Zn-N-HOPCPs, N-HOPCPs, and Zn-N-HOPCM The modified SiO2-CCT was immersed into a 45 mL of a methanol solution dissolved 8.15 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 6.75 g 2-MeIM for 50 min and then vacuum degassed for 10 min to assure that the precursor solution enters into the void of the template. Subsequently, the obtained SiO2-CCT@ZIF-8 precursor was transferred to watch glass and dried at 50 °C. Afterward, the gained SiO2-CCT@ZIF-8 precursor was immersed in a mixed solution of NH3·H2O/CH3OH (1:1 v/v) and then degassed in vacuum for 10 min to ensure that the mixed solution was homogeneously permeated. The above solution was stationary for 24 h to complete crystallization. The as-synthesized SiO2-CCT@ZIF-8 was pyrolyzed in a tube furnace under N2 atmosphere at 800 °C for 2 h with a heating ramp of 5 °C·min−1. The obtained SiO2-CCT@Zn-N-C black material was immersed in 1 M NaOH at the temperature to remove SiO2-CCT. The as-synthesized material was washed with water, and dried at 80 °C for 6 h. Finally, the Zn-N-HOPCPs was obtained. To prepare the N-HOPCPs, the above as-synthesized SiO2-CCT@ZIF-8 was pyrolyzed at 950 °C for removing Zn species (mp 420 °C, bp 907 °C). The procedure for preparing the Zn-N-HOPCM is almost the same as that of the Zn-N-HOPCPs described above except with a change of the mixed solution. For the Zn-N-HOPCM, the pure NH3·H2O was used in place of the mixed solution of NH3·H2O/CH3OH. To increase the template void utilization to form a monolithic material, all the process was repeated several times. 2.4 Synthesis of Zn-N-BMCPs First, single-crystal ZIF-8 was prepared. 515 mg of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 523 mg of 2-MeIM was dissolved in 40 mL of CH3OH, respectively. Two methanol solutions were mixed and stirred for 5 min and then remained stationary for 12 h. The white precipitate was obtained via centrifugation and washed with methanol three times and dried at 80 °C. The as-synthesized ZIF-8 was pyrolyzed in a tube furnace under N2 atmosphere at 800 °C for 2 h with a heating ramp of 5 °C·min−1. Finally, the Zn-N-BMCPs was obtained. 2.5 Preparation of 3DOM-ZIF-8 The 3DOM-ZIF-8 were fabricated using linear polystyrene (LPS) as a colloidal crystal template according to the earlier studies [42]. LPS-CCT was removed with DMF before pyrolysis. The pyrolysis process without confinement is the same as that of Zn-N-HOPCPs. 2.6 Photothermally-driven catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 In a typical procedure, epoxide (18 mmol), Zn-N-HOPCPs (60 mg), and TBAB (0.2 mmol) were added into the photoreactor and a balloon filled with CO2 was connected to the photoreactor. The CO2 was inflated several times before the reaction to guarantee a pure CO2 atmosphere. The catalytic cycloaddition reaction was carried out under light irradiation with a 300 W Xe lamp at room temperature for 10 h. The obtained products were immersed in CDCl3 and centrifuged to collect the liquid phase. The product yield was calculated by 1H NMR spectroscopy. For the recyclability test, after the first reaction, catalysts were collected and washed with ethanol and then dried at 80 °C for the next recycling utilize. For the pure Zn-N-HOPCPs, pure TBAB, N-HOPCPs, Zn-N-HOPCM, and Zn-N-BMCPs the catalytic processes are the identical as above. 2.7 Characterization The morphology and structure were acquired by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Nova NanoSEM450, 1 kV) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Talos F200S, 200 kV). The aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM) measurements were taken on a Titan Themis Cubed G2 60–300, FEI. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were investigated by a Bruker D8-Davinci equipped with Cu Kα radiation source. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a spectrometer from Thermo Scientific ESCALab-250Xi with monochromatic Al Kα radiation, and the binding energies were calibrated using the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw inVia Reflex UV Raman spectrometer with an excitation laser wavelength of λ = 532 nm. UV–visible spectra of the samples were obtained by using a UV–visible spectrophotometer (VARIAN CARY300). Nitrogen adsorption–desorption data was acquired by Micromeritics ASAP 2020. The content of Zn atoms was investigated by an Optima 7300 DV inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES). The 1H-nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were analyzed and identified by a Bruker 400 spectrometer using CDCl3 as a solvent. Their peak frequencies were referenced versus an internal standard (tetramethylsilane (TMS)). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were performed on a Bruker VECTOR-22 spectrometer on KBr pellets in the wavelength region of 4000 to 400 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure The synthesis process of the Zn-N-HOPCPs is illustrated in Scheme 1 . First, a monolithic CCT was assembled by SiO2 microspheres via centrifugation. Next, ZIF-8 single crystals with a tetrakaidecahedron morphology grow in the interstitial spaces of SiO2-CCT by nano-casting method, followed by carbonization under the inert atmosphere. After the SiO2-CCT was removed by the NaOH solution, Zn-N-HOPCPs were thus obtained. The morphological features of the as-synthesized samples were monitored SEM. The monodisperse SiO2 nanospheres with a diameter of around 190 nm were synthesized, and numerous uniform SiO2 nanospheres were self-assembled to form the monolithic CCT with a typically ordered hexagonal array (Figs. S1a–c). The ZIF-8 precursor solution, with a fixed 2-methylimidazole/Zn(NO3)2 molar ratio of 3 and containing methanol, is impregnated into the void of the SiO2-CCT. The as-obtained monolith (denoted as SiO2-CCT@ZIF-8 precursor) was put into the solution of methanol/ammonia (1:1 v/v) at room temperature, rendering the growth of ZIF-8 single crystals within SiO2-CCT. Because of the growing stress of the ZIF-8 phase, the SiO2-CCT@ZIF-8 precursor monolith is transferred into small fragments (Fig. S2). Subsequent pyrolysis in N2 at 800 °C and then removal of the SiO2-CCT yielded freestanding Zn-N-HOPCPs. The SEM images show that Zn-N-HOPCPs retained its original polyhedral shape well (Fig. 1 a and Fig. S3a). This phenomenon confirmed that the confined pyrolysis of single-crystal ZIF-8 in the colloidal crystal template gap to yield a hierarchically ordered porous Zn-N-C nanoreactor is beneficial to maintain the integrity of the original structural morphology. Furthermore, the TEM image displays an ordered 3D-interconnected macroporous structure with interconnected windows (~55 nm) between neighbor spherical chamber (Fig. S3b). The well-interconnected macropores are not only advantageous for bulky-molecule-involved reactions and offer a larger surface area but also favorable for the efficiency of light-harvesting [26]. On the contrary, single-atom Zn on N-doped bulky micro/mesoporous carbon polyhedrons (Zn-N-BMCPs) were prepared features bulky polyhedrons without ordered 3D-interconnected macroporous architecture (Figs. S4–7). Moreover, a HAADF-STEM image shows that no visible zinc-based nanoparticles or clusters can be clearly observed, suggesting that Zn atoms might exist in an atomically dispersed form (Fig. 1b). The corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) element mappings of Zn-N-HOPCPs show the homogeneous distribution of C, N, and Zn elements in the entire sample (Fig. 1c and Fig. S8). The Zn content is about 5.8 wt%, measured by ICP-AES analysis (Table S2). To corroborate the existence of isolated single-atom Zn sites, the aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM observation was performed, which clearly illustrates that well-dispersed Zn single atoms (bright dots marked with yellow cycles) are homogeneously distributed on N-doped porous carbon matrix (Fig. 1d,e and Fig. S9). To demonstrate the confined effect of SiO2-CCT, we prepared 3DOM-ZIF-8 using LPS-CCT and subsequently pyrolyzed it without confined conditions. SEM images show 3DOM-ZIF-8-derived N-doped carbon materials are prone to shrinkage and collapse of the structure (Fig. S10). These results indicate that the confined pyrolysis of single-crystal ZIF-8 in the SiO2-CCT gap to yield a hierarchically ordered porous Zn-N-C nanoreactor is beneficial to maintain the integrity of the original structural morphology. Besides, PVP modified SiO2 microspheres are also very important. SEM image shows that the structure of carbon polyhedrons is incomplete (spherical shape) and the yield is very low in the absence of PVP (Fig. S11). Combining the previously reported literature [51,52], we speculate that the carbonyl group in PVP can coordinate with Zn2+ and 2-MeIM, so that more ZIF-8 precursors are adsorbed in the SiO2-CCT voids (Fig. S1d). Furthermore, many literatures have reported that the surface of the material contains carbonyl groups, which is beneficial to the formation of ZIF-8 single crystal [53–55]. 3.2 The influence of template characteristics on morphology It is generally considered that the growth process of single-crystal ZIF-8 is from the cube composed of 6 (100) facets to the truncated rhombic dodecahedra made of 12 (110) and 6 (100) facets and finally form a rhombic dodecahedron composed of 12 (100) facets [56–58]. Interestingly, single-crystal ZIF-8 grows in a 3D-ordered colloidal crystal template to form a tetrakaidekahedron morphology composed of 6 (100) and 8 (111) facets [52]. This result is mainly due to the (100) and (111) facets in the template guiding the evolution of single-crystal ZIF-8 (Fig. S1c). A rhombic dodecahedral Zn-N-HOPCPs is also formed when the regularity of the template is poor (Fig. 2 ). Therefore, the regularity (crystal structure) of the colloidal crystal template is very important for forming the structural morphology of the single crystal ZIF-8. Besides, during the crystallization of ZIF-8, if pure NH3·H2O is used as the solvent, the precursor generates the monolithic 3DOM-ZIF-8 by homogeneous crystallization (Scheme 2 ) [52]. The SEM image shows the gained monolithic SiO2-CCT possesses a highly well-arranged structure (Fig. 3 a). The SEM images show that the ZIF-8 or ZIF-8-derived material was filled into the gap of the SiO2 microspheres (Fig. 3b and c). The SEM image clearly shows the gained Zn-N-HOPCM possesses three-dimensionally ordered inverse opal structures with a hexagonal skeleton (Fig. 3d). Moreover, the periodically ordered macroporous structures are interconnected through open windows (Fig. 3d, inset). The porous nature and compositions of the Zn-N-HOPCM are shown in Figs. S12 and 13. To explore the phases and compositions of the samples, FT-IR, XRD, and Raman spectroscopy measurements were carried out. In the spectrum of SiO2-CCT, the peak at 1105 cm−1 is associated with the Si-O band (Fig. 4 a). Compared with SiO2-CCT, the spectrum of SiO2-CCT@ZIF-8 composite shows more adsorption peaks derived from ZIF-8. The peak at 421 cm−1 is originated from the Zn-N stretch mode. The peaks at 1305 and 1387 cm−1 are derived from the imidazole ring. These results indicate that ZIF-8 has been implanted into the void space of SiO2-CCT. The FT-IR spectrum of SiO2-CCT@Zn-N-C indicates that the characteristic peaks of ZIF-8 disappeared completely, disclosing that ZIF-8 was converted to carbon-based composites (Zn-N-C) after the pyrolysis process. The disappearance of the characteristic absorbance peaks of SiO2 in the Zn-N-HOPCPs demonstrates that SiO2-CCT was fully removed. The XRD pattern of SiO2-CCT@ZIF-8 exhibits the superposition of pure ZIF-8 pattern and SiO2 pattern, which further reveal that ZIF-8 single crystals successfully grow in the gap of SiO2-CCT (Fig. 4b). The XRD pattern of Zn-N-HOPCPs shows two broad peaks at near 25° and 44° which may be associated with the characteristic graphitic carbon (002) and (100)/(101) diffractions, as further investigated by Raman spectroscopy. Notably, no diffraction peak assigned to Zn or ZnO species can be discovered, being indicative of the atomically dispersed Zn single atoms in the Zn-N-HOPCPs. According to the Raman result, the Zn-N-HOPCPs show two dominant peaks at 1360 and 1590 cm−1 arises from D band and G band of defected graphitic carbon, respectively (Fig. 4c). The G band is originated from sp2-hybridized bonded carbons, while the D band is related to the defects in carbon materials. The ID/IG values of Zn-N-HOPCPs is 1.12, suggesting the existence of abundant defect sites which not only provide additional anchor sites for metal single atoms but also could correlate with the excellent photocatalytic activity [25]. 3.3 Chemical properties and surface area XPS measurement was employed to investigate the elemental composition and chemical states of various elements. The survey XPS spectra suggest the existence of C, Si, N, O, and Zn elements in the SiO2-CCT@ZIF-8 (Fig. S14). The survey XPS spectra suggest the presence of C, N, O, and Zn elements in the Zn-N-HOPCPs (Fig. 4d), which agrees with the EDS element mappings. The high-resolution C 1s spectrum of Zn-N-HOPCPs was deconvoluted into four types of carbon species: CC (283.5 eV), CN (285.1 eV), CO (285.9 eV), and CO (287.9 eV) (Fig. 4e). The presence of carbon peaks assigned to CC and C-C bonds are consistent with Raman results. High-resolution N 1s spectrum (Fig. 4f) was fitted into three characteristic nitrogen species located at 398.6, 399.8, and 401.0 eV, ascribing to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N, respectively, which play an anchoring role for single-atom Zn. This result indicates that nitrogen successfully combined with the carbon skeleton to form N-doped porous carbon. The existence of pyridinic N and pyrrolic N species can also improve the photocatalytic activity for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides because it can serve as Lewis base sites. Recent studies demonstrated that the single-atom Zn anchored by the neighbor N atoms (Zn-N4 moieties) can be obtained by one-step pyrolysis of the ZIF-8 crystals [25,38]. In the high-resolution Zn 2p XPS spectrum, the peaks located at 1021.1 eV and 1044.2 eV are assigned to Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 of the Zn orbitals (Fig. 4g), reflecting the existence of single Zn sites in Zn-N-HOPCPs. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurement was conducted to analyze the porous structure and surface area. The isotherm of Zn-N-HOPCPs shows combined characteristics of type I and IV isotherms. The distinct steep slope at relatively low pressure (P/P0 < 0.05) and the visible hysteresis loop at the relative pressure range of 0.4–1.0P/P0 indicated the coexistence of micropore (<2 nm) and mesopores (2–50 nm) (Fig. 4h). The porous character was further manifested by the pore size distribution of Zn-N-HOPCPs with pore diameter mostly concentrated at approximately 0.55, 0.8, 1.2, and 4 nm (Fig. 4i). Strikingly, the Zn-N-HOPCPs possess larger specific surface area (1128 m2·g−1) and pore volume (0.90 cm3·g−1) compared to Zn-N-BMCPs (855 m2·g−1, 0.68 cm3·g−1), indicating that the template-assisted method is beneficial to increase the specific surface area of N-doped carbon polyhedron (Table S2). These results indicate that the template-assisted pyrolysis approach can effectively convert an N-doped micropore-dominant carbon polyhedron into a hierarchical porosity (macro-/meso-/micropores), which often contributes to facilitate the reactivity of internal active sites and expedite the mass diffusion of reactants/products. 3.4 Photocatalytic performance of different catalysts Efficient CO2 photoconversion to cyclic carbonates is viewed as a promising approach for the synthesis of high-value-added chemicals and has spurred significant scientific and technological interest [15,25]. It is noteworthy that Zn-N-HOPCPs exhibit a wide range of light responses (230–800 nm), covering the ultraviolet and visible light (Fig. S15), which will facilitate photocatalytic driving of conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonates under mild conditions. To illustrate the merit of the hierarchically ordered porous structure of Zn-N-HOPCPs for CO2 cycloaddition, the control experiments with the product of N-HOPCPs, Zn-N-HOPCM, and Zn-N-BMCPs were carried out. Cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide was first chosen for a typical reaction. As illustrated in Table 1 and Fig. S16, when Zn-N-HOPCPs as the catalyst and tetrabutyl ammonium bromide (TBAB) as the co-catalyst, the catalytic yield is as high as 95% (entry 1) at normal temperature and pressure. Interestingly, when Zn-N-HOPCPs or TBAB as the only catalyst, the catalytic yield is drastically reduced to 17% and <5%, which reveals that Zn-N-HOPCPs and TBAB are vital for the highly efficient catalytic CO2 cycloaddition (entry 2 and 3). Since the CO2 cycloaddition reaction is endothermic, the yield drops to <5% without light irradiation, demonstrating the significance of the photothermal effect to the reaction (entry 4). Meanwhile, the light-to-heat conversion performance was studied by directly heating instead of light irradiation. The experimental results showed that the yield increases with the increase of temperature, and the yield at the heating temperature of 60 °C is close to that under light irradiation (Fig. S17). To demonstrate the importance of single-atom Zn for the reaction, the isolated single-atom Zn sites in the Zn-N-HOPCPs were removed as a controlled study (denoted as N-HOPCPs). Obviously, the yield of the cyclic carbonates dropped distinctly to 33% for N-HOPCPs, manifesting the indispensable part of single Zn atoms as Lewis acid sites (entry 5). Furthermore, the catalytic yield of the Zn-N-HOPCM with monolithic nature was 87% (entry 6), lower than that of Zn-N-HOPCPs, which might be due to the micron-sized Zn-N-HOPCPs are more conducive to light absorption. Moreover, the specific surface area of Zn-N-HOPCM (983 m2·g−1) prepared by homogeneous crystallization is slightly lower than that of Zn-N-HOPCPs (1128 m2·g−1) prepared by heterogeneous crystallization. Correspondingly, the Zn-N-BMCPs prepared by bulky ZIF-8 showed a catalytic yield of 52%, revealing that the internal active sites of the Zn-N-BMCPs have a low utilization rate (entry 7). The catalytic performance of the six catalytic systems is shown in Fig. 5 a, Zn-N-HOPCPs exhibit the highest activity with 95% of cyclic carbonate yield. Notably, we compared the Zn-N-HOPCPs with previously reported literature (Table S3). The comparison shows that the Zn-N-HOPCPs has an excellent photocatalytic performance of cycloaddition reaction at room temperature and low pressure due to the characteristics of hierarchically ordered porous and single Zn atoms. Collectively, all of these data demonstrate the potential of Zn-N-HOPCPs to boost the catalytic cycloaddition reaction because of their macro-/meso-/micropore structure, more exposed active sites, improved mass diffusion ability and superior light-harvesting ability (Fig. 5b). Based on these results and the previous progress [59,60], the tentative CO2 cycloaddition mechanism over Zn-N-HOPCPs has been proposed (Fig. 5c). First, epoxides are adsorbed and polarized by single Zn atoms, and CO2 is adsorbed and activated by neighboring N atoms. Next, the bromide ion in the TBAB nucleophilically attacks the C atoms with less steric hindrance in the epoxides, thereby causing a ring-opening reaction. Then, the oxygen anion in the ring-opened intermediate reacts with the C atom in the N-activated CO2. Afterward, CO2 is inserted into the ring-opening intermediate to form an acyclic ester. Finally, the intramolecular ring of the acyclic ester forms a cyclic carbonate. The entire catalytic process embodies the synergistic activation of single Zn atoms as Lewis acid sites and pyridine N as Lewis base in the Zn-N-HOPCPs. 3.5 The stability and mass transfer characteristics of catalyst In addition, to investigate the nature of heterogeneous catalysis of Zn-N-HOPCPs, the filtration operation was conducted after 4 h of CO2 cycloaddition (Fig. 5a). The results show that no target product was detected in the remaining 6 h under the same conditions, demonstrating the absence of active sites leaching. The stability and recyclability of Zn-N-HOPCPs were also investigated, and the results demonstrate that no remarkable performance decay was observed after five consecutive cycles (Fig. 5d). The XPS spectra and EDS elemental mapping of the recovered Zn-N-HOPCPs show that the chemical compositions match well with the original sample (Figs. S18 and 19). The SEM and TEM images of the recovered Zn-N-HOPCPs illustrate that the hierarchical porous structure was well preserved (Fig. S19). The ICP-AES data indicates that the content of Zn in the recovered Zn-N-HOPCPs is about 5.6 wt%, close to 5.8 wt% of the fresh one. These results obviously elucidate that the catalyst has satisfactory stability and recyclability, originated from its unique N-doped hierarchically ordered porous structure. Additionally, the Zn-N-HOPCPs also be used to catalyze a wide range of substrates containing epoxy groups into their corresponding cyclic carbonate (Table 2 , Figs. S20–24), illustrating its excellent tolerance to various substrates. Obviously, the Zn-N-HOPCPs still maintains excellent catalytic performance in the bulky-molecule-involved CO2 cycloaddition conversion. It is further demonstrated that the ordered hierarchical macro-/meso-/microporous structure not only facilitates the mass transfer of substrates and reactants, especially for the bulky-molecule-involved reaction but also promotes the exposure of internal active sites. Notably, epoxides with electron-withdrawing groups have higher reactivity (entry 3 and 4), while epoxides with electron-donating groups have lower reactivity (entry 5 and 6). This behavior is attributable to the electron-withdrawing groups make the substrates more vulnerable to attack by Br– of TBAB and accelerates the reactions [25]. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have illustrated a confined pyrolysis approach to fabricate isolated single-atom Zn sites anchored on N-doped hierarchically ordered porous carbon polyhedrons. The silica-confined pyrolysis transformation of the single crystal MOF to N-doped carbon single-atom catalysts is not only advantageous for maintaining the original single crystal morphology but also for forming a highly ordered macroporous structure. The as-prepared Zn-N-HOPCPs possess integrated Lewis acid (single-atom Zn) and base sites (pyridinic N), high surface area (1128 m2·g−1), large pore volume (0.90 cm3·g−1), periodically interconnected open windows (~55 nm), highly accessible micro/mesopore channels (0.55, 0.8, 1.2 and 4 nm), and abundant Zn content (5.8 wt%). Benefiting from the aforementioned merits, the Zn-N-HOPCPs show outstanding catalytic performance for catalytic CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides under mild conditions compared to Zn-N-BMCPs derived from conventional bulky ZIF-8, and Zn-N-HOPCM derived from monolithic 3DOM-ZIF-8. Particularly, the Zn-N-HOPCPs are capable of catalyzing the bulky-molecule-involved CO2 cycloaddition conversion because of the interconnected macropores. This work represents the important study on the photothermal effect of hierarchically ordered porous carbon decorated with isolated single-atom Zn sites towards catalytic CO2 cycloaddition under mild conditions. This silica-confined pyrolysis strategy will open an avenue to fabricate other MOF-derived single-atom catalysts with hierarchical structures for energy-related applications such as photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. coredata.dc:description: Rational design and fabrication of metal–organic framework (MOF)-derived ordered hierarchical macro-/meso-/microporous N-doped carbon materials featured with the atomically dispersed metal atoms can effectively enhance their catalytic performance. Herein we develop a template-assisted strategy, namely the confined growth and pyrolysis of single-crystalline zeolite imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) in three-dimensional ordered template voids, to create hierarchical porosity in MOFs-derived N-doped carbon materials. The as-synthesized single-atom Zn on N-doped hierarchically ordered porous carbon polyhedrons (Zn-N-HOPCPs) show integrated Lewis acid (single-atom Zn) and base sites (pyridinic N), high surface area (1128 m2·g−1), large pore volume (0.90 cm3·g−1), periodically interconnected open windows (~55 nm), highly accessible micro/mesopore channels (0.55, 0.8, 1.2, and 4 nm), and abundant Zn content (5.8 wt%). The hierarchical nanoarchitecture (macro-/meso-/micropores) significantly facilitates mass transfer for bulky-molecule-involved reactions and exposes inside active sites, resulting in satisfactory CO2 photoconversion under mild conditions. The strategy presented here sheds light on the design and fabrication of various hierarchically ordered porous carbon decorated with atomically dispersed metal atoms for other important applications.
coredata.dc:title: Confined pyrolysis transformation of ZIF-8 to hierarchically ordered porous Zn-N-C nanoreactor for efficient CO2 photoconversion under mild conditions
